channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Tensions Pose Early, and Perilous, Test for Trump
item.media:description: This photograph distributed by North Korea’s state news agency on Tuesday purports to show the launch of four ballistic missiles.
item.description: The North’s provocations and Chinese anger over the deployment of a missile defense system in South Korea are creating a difficult balancing act for the new administration.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, CHOE SANG-HUN, CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: New Israel Law Bars Foreign Critics From Entering the Country
item.media:description: A banner calling for the boycott, divestment and sanctioning of Israel hanging from the Manhattan Bridge in New York during a protest against Israel’s military campaign in Gaza in 2014.
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.description: The measure set off alarms in the United States, where Israel’s critics and some of its most loyal Jewish supporters alike warned that it would further isolate the country.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: For Trump and Netanyahu, a Budding Symbiotic Relationship
item.media:description: President Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu during the Israeli Prime Minister’s recent visit to Washington.
item.description: President Trump and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel seem eager to build a mutually beneficial political friendship by playing a supportive role for each other on key issues.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Astana Journal: Kazakh Capital, a Post-Soviet Creation, Is Growing Real Roots
item.media:description: A view from the Rixos President Astana Hotel in Kazakhstan, where Syrian peace negotiations have taken place.
item.description: In 1993, Kazakhstan’s president moved the capital to what is now Astana, blending elements of its Islamic roots with a dose of a personality cult.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: South Africa Reverses Withdrawal From International Criminal Court
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa at a National Defense Force parade in Durban last month. His government has long said the International Criminal Court is biased against African states.
item.description: In a letter to the United Nations secretary general, the country cited a recent court ruling that declared an exit “unconstitutional and invalid.”
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Son of Kim Jong-nam Appears to Surface in YouTube Video
item.media:description: News reports in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday showed a young man who identified himself as Kim Han-sol, the son of Kim Jong-nam.
item.description: In the video, a man who calls himself Kim Han-sol shows what seems to be his North Korean passport and says that he is in hiding with his mother and sister.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: China Tries to Defuse Tensions Over North Korea
item.media:description: American soldiers during a military exercise in Paju, South Korea, near the border with North Korea, on Tuesday. The United States began assembling a missile defense system in South Korea this week.
item.description: China called on the North to suspend its nuclear program in exchange for a halt to U.S.-South Korean military drills. But it was far from clear the idea would gain traction.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Few Clues as Malaysia Airlines Mystery Marks Its Third Anniversary
item.media:description: In Beijing on Wednesday, relatives of passengers on a Malaysia Airlines flight missing for three years called on the Chinese government to continue the search.
item.description: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 remains one of the biggest aviation mysteries of all time. Here’s a look at some of our coverage.
item.dc:creator: DANIELLE BELOPOTOSKY

item.title: Kabul Military Hospital in Afghanistan Comes Under Attack
item.media:description: A helicopter from the Afghan National Army arriving at a military hospital in Kabul, the capital, on Wednesday. The hospital is the main care center for wounded Afghan army soldiers.
item.description: A suicide bomber had detonated his explosives at the main military hospital before other assailants entered the building, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Lynne Stewart, Lawyer Imprisoned in Terrorism Case, Dies at 77
item.media:description: Lynne F. Stewart in 2004. As a lawyer, she represented violent, self-described revolutionaries.
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Stewart, who was convicted of aiding terrorism in her representation of Omar Abdel Rahman, was also known for defending a member of the Weather Underground and other violent activists.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH P. FRIED

item.title: WikiLeaks Reignites Tensions Between Silicon Valley and Spy Agencies
item.media:description: A pedestrian walked by the Apple Store on Fifth Avenue in February 2016 in Manhattan, while a group of demonstrators protested F.B.I. efforts to force Apple to help access the iPhone of an attacker in the 2015 shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.
item.description: Leaked documents appear to indicate that the C.I.A. was collecting cyberweapons that can break into smartphones and even internet-connected televisions.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Top U.S. General Discusses Syria With Counterparts From Russia and Turkey
item.media:description: A convoy of United States armored vehicles in Manbij, northern Syria. A Pentagon spokesman said Monday that the deployment was intended as a “visible sign of deterrence and reassurance” to dissuade Turkish-backed militias and other groups from attacking the area.
item.description: The meeting was called to discuss how to avoid an unintended confrontation as forces from all three nations operate on an increasingly crowded battlefield in northern Syria.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: For I.P.O., Saudi Oil Company May Have to Give Up Some of Its Secrets
item.media:description: An oil complex under construction in December 2011 in Jubail, Saudi Arabia — a joint venture between Saudi Aramco and a foreign oil company. An initial public offering of Saudi Aramco is expected by the end of 2018.
item.description: Some bankers think the state-held Saudi Aramco is worth only a fraction of the value it claims. Investors are pushing for transparency before its initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: House of Lords Votes for Parliament to Have More Say on ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: The House of Lords voted to give Britain’s Parliament a greater say over the outcome of talks on exiting the European Union.
item.description: The Lords sought more influence over a deal to leave the European Union than just the up-or-down vote offered by Prime Minister Theresa May.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Before Elections, Dutch Fear Russian Meddling, but Also U.S. Cash
item.media:description: Geert Wilders at a campaign stop in Spijkenisse, the Netherlands, last month. The far-right Dutch lawmaker has drawn support from some American conservatives.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: American conservative activists are supporting Europe’s far-right figures like Geert Wilders, who are campaigning against the European Union.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM and CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Major Christian Charity Is Closing India Operations Amid a Crackdown
item.media:description: Pramod Dass, the director of Bethesda Charitable Endeavors, one of the 500 Indian partners of Compassion International that will have to shut down operations.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: The group, Compassion International, which runs a “sponsor a child” program, is leaving India after 48 years amid pressure from the Modi government.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: White Rhinoceros Is Killed for Its Horn at Wildlife Park Near Paris
item.media:description: Vince, the 4-year-old rhinoceros killed at a wildlife park west of Paris.
item.media:credit: Domaine de Thoiry Zoo, via Associated Press
item.description: The horn of the 4-year-old rhinoceros, named Vince, was sawed off in the episode, according to officials at the Parc Zoologique de Thoiry.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Hungary Approves Detention of Asylum Seekers in Guarded Camps
item.media:description: Building a fence on the border with Serbia in southern Hungary this month.
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban said the measure would act as a deterrent against migration, which he called the “Trojan horse of terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Pleas for Somalia, on the Brink of Famine
item.description: United Nations officials in Somalia on Tuesday appealed to the international community for $825 million to address drought, cholera and starvation affecting about 5.5 million people, about half the country's population.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump Is Wrong About Guantánamo Detainees
item.media:description: A United States soldier inside the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
item.description: President Trump’s assertion that 122 former prisoners released during the Obama administration have returned to militant activity is false.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Australian Police Stopped a Car for Unpaid Fuel. They Found a Nightmare.
item.media:description: Detective Inspector Paul Hart in Toowoomba, Queensland, Australia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Officers stopped a woman after she failed to pay for gasoline, and after noticing her facial injuries, they found a man hiding in the vehicle. He was charged.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: WikiLeaks Releases Trove of Alleged C.I.A. Hacking Documents
item.media:description: The C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va. If the WikiLeaks documents are authentic, the release would be a serious blow to the agency.
item.description: The documents describe agency tools used to hack into smartphones and TVs, as well as to bypass encryption on programs like Signal and WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ANDREW W. LEHREN

item.title: IHT Retrospective Blog: 1917: Plot to Kill the President Is Discovered
item.description: A 31-year-old German is reported to have confessed to playing a role in a plot to assassinate President Wilson.
item.dc:creator: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Pakistan Reopens Border With Afghanistan for 2 Days
item.media:description: People headed into Afghanistan at the reopened Torkham border crossing in Pakistan on Tuesday.
item.description: The frontier, which had been closed 18 days ago over security concerns, was opened temporarily to allow Afghans stranded in Pakistan to return home.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: U.N. Chief, Visiting Somalia, Pleads for Aid to Avert Famine
item.media:description: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Secretary General António Guterres has warned that millions of people in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen are at risk from deadly hunger.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Attacks by Rebels in Myanmar Leave Dozens Dead
item.media:description: A victim wounded in an attack by rebels in Laukkai, Myanmar, arrived at a local hospital on Monday.
item.description: The assaults by an ethnic Chinese group were said to have targeted a hotel, casinos and police and army posts in an escalation of a long-running conflict.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and MIKE IVES

item.title: High Court Asked to Limit Detention of Asylum Seekers in Australia for Care
item.media:description: Asylum seekers with their ID cards after landing on Manus Island, Papua New Guinea, in 2013. Rights groups have assailed the conditions in such offshore camps.
item.media:credit: Eoin Blackwell/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.description: A legal aid group is challenging the extended detention of asylum seekers transferred to Australia from offshore camps for medical treatment or other temporary purposes.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MALIK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China Warns of Arms Race After U.S. Deploys Missile Defense in South Korea
item.media:description: Soldiers guarded the entrance to a golf course where the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system will be deployed in Seongju, South Korea, on Tuesday.
item.description: Beijing denounced the United States’ decision to use the Thaad technology and vowed to “take the necessary steps to safeguard our own security interests.”
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Almost Every Week Is Fashion Week Somewhere in the World
item.media:description: Models in Vivian Bennet designs at Africa Fashion Week last summer in Lagos. The idea of holding a fashion week has taken root around the world.
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Why so many countries are now engaged in a race to establish their own ready-to-wear showcase. Or two. Or three.
item.dc:creator: VINCENT BEVINS

item.title: Iraqi Forces Enter Western Mosul, in Fierce Battle Against ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi forces fighting Islamic State militants in western Mosul on Tuesday.
item.description: The chief of the federal police said that soldiers had retaken a government compound, a branch of the central bank and an archaeological museum.
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Best Country in the World? Survey Says It’s Switzerland
item.media:description: For the first time, Switzerland took the top spot on an annual survey of the best countries.
item.description: Its attitude toward education, democracy, business and quality of life helped a European nation top the list. The United States slipped to No. 7.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
